newsitem.title: USA: Brazil stirs debt market with Brady swap/buyback.
newsitem.headline: Brazil stirs debt market with Brady swap/buyback.

text.p: Brazil stunned the emerging debt market on Wednesday by offering to either swap Brady bonds for 30-year global bonds or repurchase the Bradies outright via Goldman Sachs and J.P. Morgan.
New York dealers pegged initial price talk for the global bonds at around 400 basis points over U.S. Treasuries.
"It looks like it will be well received, and the U.S. Treasury market will be friendly for this type of offering," said Thomas Trebat, managing director at Citicorp Securities.
The offer, which had been discussed as an option since Mexico conducted a similar exchange last May, led to a dramatic price rise for the affected instruments.

Brazil said it would either pay investors cash for their Par bonds, and Discount Z-L bonds or it would swap Pars, Discounts, or "C" bonds Bradies for a $1.0 billion issue of 30-year uncollaterized, SEC-registered global bonds.
After the news, the liquid "C" bond rose above a 79 bid, and settled 1-3/8 higher at 78-5/8 by late morning, while Discounts stood 1-3/4 higher at 82-7/8, and Pars were up 1-1/8 to 66.
"It was very frantic but right now it's very calm," said Marcelo Fleury, vice president at Garban Corp. "It's not an innovation, but for Brazil it's very good news."
Brady bond dealers said that, while prices might slip from their highs, the market had plenty of reason to speculate on the upside.
The offer will expire at 1500 EDT/1900 GMT on June 3, unless extended or ended earlier by Brazil.
The Pars would be valued at 250 basis points over the November 2026 T-bond, and the "C" bond would be set at 460 basis points over May 2007 T-bond. Discounts will be fixed at $818.75 per $1,000.

The global bond will be priced through a modified Dutch auction. Brazil will select a single clearing spread, which, along with the yield of the November 2026 T-bond, will determine the yield and price of the global bonds.
Investors may also purchase the global bond for cash, as long as the cash sale does not exceed 25 percent of the total issue.
Analysts applauded the offer, explaining the new global bond would dramatically extend the country's yield curve.
"This is definately a step in the right direction," said Raul Elizalde, head of quantitative analysis at ING Barings. "What this allows is a better yield curve for Brazil."
